Federal Court
Pinard, J.
April 30, 2004.
Counsel:
Alain Joffe, for the plaintiff;
Lucie St-Pierre, for the defendant.
Solicitors of Record:
Alain Joffe, Montreal, Quebec, for the plaintiff;
Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the defendant.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
Judge Pinard
: This is an application for judicial review of the decision of the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board (the IRB) rendered on February 26, 2003, ruling that the applicant is not a "refugee" within the meaning of the Convention nor a "person in need of protection" according to the definitions given in sections 96 and 97 respectively of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, ch. 27.

[2]
Leticia Obeng (the plaintiff) is a Christian and a citizen of Ghana where she is a member of the Akan tribe. She alleges that she fears persecution due to her participation in a social group, women, because her father forced her to marry a Muslim man who demanded that she undergo female genital mutilation.

[3]
The IRB concluded that the applicant was neither a Convention "refugee" nor a "person in need of protection" because her allegations were not credible.

[4]
The IRB provided several reasons why it concluded that the Applicant's account was not credible. The court noted, among other things, the inconsistency between the plaintiff's allegation that she fears her father and the information contained in the Certificate of Registration in the Birth Registry, the plaintiff's omission to mention her fear of Mr. Banda at the point of entry, and the implausibility of the plaintiff's statements about the financial means that allowed her to undertake the trip to Canada. A review of the file reveals that the plaintiff's explanations in this regard were simply deemed insufficient. In <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , the Federal Court of Appeal held that the court's perception that the applicant is not credible on an important aspect of the claim can lead to the conclusion that there is no credible element on which the claim can be based. The court was therefore justified in relying on these inconsistencies, omissions and implausibilities to conclude that the plaintiff was not credible in view of her subjective fear.

[5]
As I indicated previously, notably in the judgment <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> [2004] A.C.F. no. 486 (QL): "In similar circumstances, the IRB can conclude against a claimant of refugee status or person in need of protection without having to consider his objective fear of persecution or the necessity of having to grant protection to persons other than him with regard to his country of origin."

[6]
En conséquence, la demande de contrôle judiciaire est rejetée.

Federal Court
Pinard, J.
April 30, 2004.
Counsel:
Alain Joffe, for the plaintiff;
Lucie St-Pierre, for the defendant.
Solicitors of Record:
Alain Joffe, Montreal, Quebec, for the plaintiff;
Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the defendant.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.
[1]
Le juge Pinard
: Il s'agit d'une demande de contrôle judiciaire de la décision de la Section de la protection des réfugiés de la Commission de l'immigration et du statut de réfugié(la CISR) rendue le 26 février 2003, statuant que la demanderesse n'est pas une "réfugiée" au sens de la Convention ni une "personne à protéger" selon les définitions données aux articles 96 et 97 respectivement de la Loi sur l'immigration et la protection des réfugiés, L.C. 2001, ch. 27.
[2]
Leticia Obeng (la demanderesse) est chrétienne et citoyenne du Ghana où elle est membre de la tribu Akan. Elle allègue craindre la persécution en raison de sa participation dans un groupe social, les femmes, parce que son père l'a forcée à épouser un homme musulman qui exige qu'elle subisse une mutilation génitale des femmes.
[3]
La CISR a conclu que la demanderesse n'est ni une "réfugiée" au sens de la Convention ni une "personne à protéger" parce que ses allégations n'étaient pas crédibles.
[4]
La CISR a indiqué plusieurs raisons pour lesquelles elle a conclu que le récit de la demanderesse n'était pas crédible. Le tribunal a noté, entre autres, l'incohérence entre l'allégation de la demanderesse qu'elle craint son père et l'information contenue dans le Certificat d'enregistrement dans le registre des naissances, l'omission par la demanderesse de mentionner sa crainte de M. Banda au point d'entrée, et l'invraisemblance des déclarations de la demanderesse au sujet des moyens financiers qui lui ont permis d'entreprendre le voyage au Canada. Une révision du dossier révèle que les explications de la demanderesse à cet égard ont tout simplement été jugées insuffisantes. Dans l'arrêt  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , la Cour d'appel fédérale a statué que la perception du tribunal que le demandeur n'est pas crédible sur un aspect important de la demande peut mener à la conclusion qu'il n'existe aucun élément crédible sur lequel la demande peut se fonder. Le tribunal était donc justifiéde se fonder sur ces incohérence, omission et invraisemblance pour conclure que la demanderesse n'était pas crédible en regard de sa crainte subjective.
[5]
Comme je l'ai indiqué antérieurement, notamment dans l'arrêt  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  [2004] A.C.F. no 486 (QL): "En semblables circonstances, la CISR peut conclure à l'encontre d'un revendicateur du statut de réfugié ou de personne à protéger sans avoir à considérer sa crainte objective de persécution ou la nécessité de devoir accorder la protection à d'autres personnes que lui en regard de son pays d'origine."
[6]
En conséquence, la demande de contrôle judiciaire est rejetée.

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, ch. 27 (sections 96 and 97)
legal_issues: The standard of evidence required to establish a claim for refugee status or protection.
The permissible weight given to credibility assessments in determining refugee status or protection.
The circumstances under which inconsistencies, omissions, or implausibilities in an applicant's testimony can justify a denial of refugee status or protection.
The scope of review of administrative decisions regarding refugee status or protection.
Whether an assessment of subjective fear of persecution is required when credibility is found lacking.
The definition of 'refugee' and 'person in need of protection' under applicable legislation.
factual_background: A citizen of Ghana, identifying as Christian and a member of the Akan tribe, applied for refugee status and protection in Canada.
The applicant alleges a fear of persecution based on gender, specifically as a woman, due to being forced by her father to marry a Muslim man.
The husband allegedly demands the applicant undergo female genital mutilation.
The Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) denied the applicant's claim, citing a lack of credibility.
The IRB identified inconsistencies between the applicant's statements and documentation, including a birth registry.
The applicant did not initially disclose a fear of an individual named Mr. Banda upon entry into Canada.
The IRB found the applicant's explanation regarding the financial means of travel to Canada to be insufficient.
The IRB's decision was subject to judicial review.

Applicants: She fears persecution due to her participation in a social group (women) in Ghana.
Her father forced her to marry a Muslim man who demands she undergo female genital mutilation.
She is a Christian and a citizen of Ghana, a member of the Akan tribe.

She provided explanations for inconsistencies regarding her financial means, fear of her father, and failure to disclose fear of Mr. Banda at the port of entry (though these were deemed insufficient by the IRB).
Respondents: The applicant's allegations are not credible.
There is an inconsistency between the applicant’s claim of fearing her father and information in her birth registry.
The applicant failed to mention her fear of Mr. Banda at the point of entry.
The applicant’s statements regarding her financial means to travel to Canada are implausible.
The applicant's explanations for the inconsistencies and omissions were inadequate.

court_analysis: The court upheld the Immigration and Refugee Board’s (IRB) decision denying refugee status and protection to the applicant, Leticia Obeng.
The IRB’s determination was based on a lack of credibility regarding the applicant’s claims of fearing persecution.

The court found the IRB was justified in relying on inconsistencies in the applicant’s account – specifically, discrepancies between her fear of her father and birth registry information, her failure to disclose fear of Mr. Banda upon entry, and implausible statements about her financial resources – to conclude her subjective fear was not credible.
The court referenced Federal Court of Appeal precedent establishing that a perceived lack of credibility on a key aspect of a claim can justify rejecting the entire claim.

The court affirmed the principle that when credibility is lacking, the IRB does not need to assess the objective fear of persecution or the broader country conditions, as established in prior case law ([2004] A.C.F. no. 486 (QL)).
The court determined the IRB’s assessment of credibility was within its jurisdiction and properly applied, leading to the dismissal of the judicial review application.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is dismissed.
